Problem:
Consider a mathematical model of a fluid flow which density ρ at a point (x, y, z) in space varies over time. The flow is defined by the differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial \\rho}{\\partial t} = -\\nabla \\cdot (\\rho \\mathbf{v}) \\), where \\( \\mathbf{v} \\) is the velocity field. An intervention is modeled by a transformation \\( g(\\rho) = \\rho \\exp(-kt) \\), with k being a positive constant.

Can we deduce the original density \\( \\rho_0 \\) after observing \\( \\rho(t) \\) at t = T without knowing whether \\( g(\\rho) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowledge of the application of \\( g(\\rho) \\), the transformation involving the exponential decay makes it impossible to accurately trace back to \\( \\rho_0 \\) as the same observed density distribution at t = T could result from various initial conditions altered by different k values.
